Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing and Assessing Effective Cyberlearning within the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative project involving the University of California, Davis (Award DUE-1525862), Diablo Valley College (Award DUE-1525057), Howard University (Award DUE-1524638), the College of Saint Benedict (Award DUE-1525021), Hope College (Award DUE-1524990), and the University of Arkansas, Little Rock (Award DUE-1525037).

This project will expand the content and capabilities of the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary, which was launched to provide vetted Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) learning resources to the public in the form of easily accessible, online college textbooks that alleviate the rising costs of postsecondary education. The STEMWiki Hyperlibrary consists of a number of connected, discipline-focused hypertext applications (ChemWiki, BioWiki, MathWiki, StatWiki, GeoWiki, PhysWiki), which are freely accessible to students regardless of socioeconomic or educational backgrounds. The ChemWiki (http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu) is currently the most developed STEMWiki, with millions of visits each month. By making high-quality STEM learning resources readily available, the project will positively impact at least four main populations: (1) the non-science community; (2) socioeconomically disadvantaged students; (3) smaller or financially disadvantaged academic institutions, including high schools, that wish to adopt new learning technologies but cannot afford the initial steep costs of a new curriculum; and (4) discipline-based education researchers looking for a platform on which to evaluate new interdisciplinary approaches and curriculum modifications, which would otherwise absorb too large of a budget to develop from scratch. Once sufficiently developed, the Hyperlibary will be a power platform for the dissemination of new educational content and the evaluation of emerging educational technologies.

The STEMWiki Hyperlibrary is designed as a collaboratively constructed learning environment that enables the dissemination and evaluation of new educational resources and approaches as online course textbooks, with an emphasis on data-driven assessment of student learning and performance. The STEMWikis allow learners to cooperatively construct and organize knowledge, providing an important alternative to "one size fits all" instruction in which content is presented in a static, prepackaged manner. In this project, the investigators will augment the constituent STEMWikis of the Hyperlibrary with ancillary homework and simulation applications, as well as formative assessment modules. They will integrate the content of the STEMWikis both horizontally (across multiple STEM fields) and vertically (across multiple levels of complexity) within a network that will provide not just single textbooks but a rich "hyperlibrary" through which new, interconnected STEM textbooks can be constructed. The result will be an easy-to-use platform on which faculty members can collaborate to create and publish reusable, online pedagogical content. The project team will add ancillary online homework (the Student Ability Rating and Inquiry System [SARIS]) and simulations (via the ChemCollective, http://www.chemcollective.org). From these components, they will build an assessment infrastructure that tracks and correlates use of individual Wiki-based textbooks with simulations, homework activity, and exam performance, with the goal of identifying and tracking student performance across multiple STEM curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award, we have improved the utility of the STEMWiki Hyperlibrary, which has been renamed to LibreTexts, and we have assessed the benefits of online educational materials relative to traditional materials (i.e. textbooks). Since its inception in 2008, LibreTexts has grown to be one of the premier open education resources (OERs) worldwide. As of August 2018 LibreTexts has accumulated over 220 million pageviews and over a millennium of confirmed reading. Moreover, the project is ranked about 7,000th of all sites on the web surpassing most federally funded education projects. We attract approximately 60 million pageviews annually with content distributed in a broad network with more than 70,000 pages of content over twelve Living Libraries. Through courses that use LibreTexts as their primary resource rather than traditional textbooks, students have saved over $30 million.

 

The Hope College team has ported the widely-used ChemPRIME textbook (over 670 pages of content including 1500 images) into LibreTexts and has fine tuned it with regard to multimedia to abide by best practices in the literature. Additionally, more of the original ChemEd DL resources were integrated into LibreTexts (after securing permission from the American Chemical Society), such as integrated chemical data and molecule structure databases, multimedia, and an interactive periodic table. One of the benefits of online for multimedia is that we can incorporate any meaningful images or graphics that are helpful, without regard for cost of printing or congesting a page. Research has shown that the use of specific types of multimedia are helpful for learning and should be used.

 

We have also conducted a full review of physical textbooks relative to the online LibreText ChemPRIME textbook for use of multimedia. We found that the freedom to incorporate as many images and videos into the online platform as needed meant that there was greater coverage of concepts using multimedia than in any hardcopy textbook.

 

We also used web analytics to study the use of links from LibreText to other pages within LibreTexts to get feedback on how best to build the learning resources and connect content between pages. We found that the most used links were ones that were conceptually similar, or that the author specifically pointed out to be useful. This information helps to guide best practices for how to incorporate and reinforce links in the online textbooks.

 

Our team has begun to also add materials in LibreTexts for introductory chemistry laboratory courses. These laboratory materials include both English and Spanish language versions.

 

These findings have been disseminated at high profile meetings including American Chemical Society National Meetings and the Biennial Conference on Chemical Education through several research presentations by faculty and undergraduate students, and through workshops put on by the PIs. Results will be further communicated through three manuscripts that are currently in preparation.

 

Finally, two undergraduate students were trained in research methods and educational practice. One is still an undergraduate at Hope College and the other is currently serving as a mathematics teacher in secondary education in the public school system in Michigan.
